xString.value: Microarrays which detect products of expression give us a snapshot of the state of a cell at a particular point in time
For a microarray care must be taken when defining 'standard' state of cell expression - ie cancer vs 'normal' samples
Expression changes between differentiated cell types, stages of the cell cycle, and accumulated exposure to environment
In any living organism, thousands of genes and their products (i.e., RNA and proteins), function in a complicated and orchestrated way that control life.

However, traditional molecular biology methods generally work on a "one gene in one experiment" basis, which means that the throughput is very limited and the "whole picture" of gene function is hard to obtain.

In the last 20 years, DNA microarray has attracted tremendous interests among biologists. This technology promised to monitor the whole genome on a single chip so that researchers can have a better picture of the interactions among thousands of genes simultaneously.

DNA Microarrays are small, solid supports onto which the sequences complementary to genes/genomic DNA are immobilized, or attached, at fixed locations. The supports themselves are commonly microscope slides, but can also be silicon chips or nylon membranes. The DNA is printed, spotted, or actually synthesised directly onto the support.
An important feature is to be able to reduce size, due to the large number of probes used.
DNA complementarity and hybridisation is exploited to detect target sequences
Probes are synthesized and then "spotted" onto glass.
Fine pins or needles controlled by a robotic arm that is dipped into wells containing DNA probes and then depositing each probe at designated locations on the array surface.
The resulting "grid" of probes is ready to receive complementary
This technique is used to produce "in-house" printed microarrays from their own labs.
Much of the excitement surrounding DNA microarray technology came from its widespread potential impact in such important areas as:
Hybridized with cDNA prepared from two samples

The two Cy-labeled cDNA samples are mixed and hybridized to a single microarray that is then scanned in a microarray scanner to visualize fluorescence of the two fluorophores after excitation with a laser beam of a defined wavelength.
Relative intensities of each fluorophore may then be used in ratio-based analysis to identify up-regulated and down-regulated genes

Oligonucleotide microarrays often carry control probes designed to hybridize with RNA spike-ins. The degree of hybridization between the spike-ins and the control probes is used to normalize the hybridization measurements for the target probes.
In oligonucleotide microarrays (or single-channel microarrays), the probes are designed to match parts of the sequence of known or predicted mRNAs.
The arrays provide intensity data for each probe or probe set indicating a relative level of hybridization with the labeled target.

There are commercially available designs that cover complete genomes from companies such as GE Healthcare, Affymetrix, or Agilent. These microarrays give estimations of the absolute value of gene expression and therefore the comparison of two conditions requires the use of two separate microarrays.
More expensive, two chips are needed
Transcription of a gene produces mRNA
mRNA then translated to produce a protein product
Up to 30,000 genes represented per microarray
Measures levels of mRNA for each gene
Many millions of SNPs in the human genome
Can provide a detailed SNP genotype/haplotype
Potential to associate genotype with disease
Also very common in cancer cells
BAC arrays Up to 32,000 ~150kb long overlapping probes per microarray
Oligonucleotide arrays Up to 1 million 60bp long, 3Kb spaced probes per microarray
: GeneChip Technology, Gene expression analysis and SNP detection microarrays
: Gene expression, SNP detection, CGH, ChIP
GeneChip design provides room for many control hybridisations
Uses perfect match (PM) and mismatch (MM) control hybridisations to control for experimental variation and non-specific hybridisation
For gene expression analysis each gene is represented by 10-20 oligo (25mer) probes Each probe has a mismatch partner, differing by central bp
Not comparative (ie two samples mixed) just looking at what is in the sample:
Averages 4 probes per exon, 40 probes per gene
QC can identify questionable genes and biological replicates
Limit findings with statistical analysis and clustering
Microarray and RNAseq technology allows us to monitor the level of expression of thousands of genes in a single analysis.
Examine regulatory/signaling/metabolic pathways affected by condition/treatment
You want to measure biological variation
Numerous methods and choice depends on:
Normalise each gene and each array...
chips are re-scaled so the average values of these housekeeping genes are equal across all chips
Attempts to remove technical variation within the dataset
didnt a/c for non-linearity (e.g. dye bias)
For each condition, calculate the median value for all genes
1. Take the median of calculated medians
2. Subtract median value from each gene
Enforces the chips to have identical intensity distribution:
Compute mean intensity in each rank across the chips and divide them into a number of quantiles
Replace each of the values in a given quantile with the mean value in that quantile across all the chips
In Affymetrix arrays, a probe-set is dedicated to each target.
A probe-set is composed by several probes (classically 11) all targeting the probe-set target sequence.
The RNA degradation plot proposes to plot the average intensity of each probes across all probe-sets, ordered from the 5 to the 3 end.
RNA degradation starts from the 5 end of the molecule
Probe intensities is lowered at that 5' end of a probe set when compared to the 3 end.
The RNA degradation plot aims at visualizing this trend.
RNA which is too degraded will have a very high slope from 5' to 3'.

The standardized slope of the curves is thus used as a quantitative indicator of the RNA degradation. An array with unexpected degradation is identified because it has a bigger slope and should stand out.
Plotting all the probe intensities in the pattern of the chip layout lets us see spatial anomalies on the chip
These two show significant overall intensity differences
These two clearly have odd patches
Technical variability will affect any down stream statistical analysis
Need to be confident of genes and samples
Average values across replicates Only if the variation is not so great
Go back to your experimental design Try to locate potential sources of variation e.g. date of experiment, culture batches
Aim is to find set of genes that show statistically significant differences for a specified condition, time point etc
Marker genes that discriminate diseased from healthy subjects
Data pre-processing can have an impact Normalisation and QC
Experimental clusters -> infer temporal/dynamics of relationship
Clusters of similar expression level -> infer regulatory/functional relationship
MIAME - Minimal Information About Microarray Experiments
The raw data for each hybridization (e.g., CEL or GPR files)
(e.g., the gene expression data matrix used to draw the conclusions from the study)
The essential sample annotation including experimental factors and their values
(e.g., compound and dose in a dose response experiment)
The experimental design including sample data relationships
(e.g., which raw data file relates to which sample)
(e.g., gene identifiers, genomic coordinates, probe oligonucleotide sequences or reference commercial array catalog number)
The essential laboratory and data processing protocols
(e.g., what normalization method has been used to obtain the final processed data)
Background noise is inevitable in almost any imaging technology
You need to be confident that the colour intensity you're seeing is a true reflection of the expression of a given gene
to remove the effect of unspecific binding
Different MA platforms have specific sets of background correction methods that are dependent on the fluorescence dye used, the light source and the scanner used
MAS 5.0 divides the microarray (more precisely, the CEL file) into 16 regions.
In each region, the intensity of the dimmest 2% of features is used to define the background level.
Each probe is then adjusted by a weighted average of these 16 values, with the weights depending on the distance to the centroids of the 16 regions.
Second, they try to model the distribution of PM intensities as a sum of:
and normal noise with mean and variance 2 (truncated at 0 to avoid negatives).
If we observe a signal X = x at a PM feature, we adjust it by
you don't have to worry about the model formula here
Techniques to integrate, interpret, analyse and visualise biological data sets (Mon-Wed)
Bioinformatics analysis methodologies and expertise in common bioinformatics software packages, tools and algorithms including workflow management tools (All week)
Work with multi-disciplinary colleagues to design life-science experiments that will generate data suitable for subsequent bioinformatics analysis
Identify and define appropriate computing infrastructure requirements for the analysis of such biological data.
Build and test analytical pipelines, or write and test new algorithms as necessary for the analysis of biological data.
